title: How to create a Bootable Partition on your PC/Laptop

forumNotes.author: Uncle_HQ
forumNotes.content:
I have 2 separate questions and would appreciate your advice: 1) I have a bootable CD for Acronis Boot Agent. I want to create a bootable partition on my PC/Laptop, from a bootable CD (containing this Acronis Boot Agent). I am trying to achieve the following; When the bootloader / boot manager loads up, it should give me the options to (1) Boot from Windows 7 (2) Boot to Acronis Boot Agent So my question is, how can I setup a new partition on my hard drive which would contain the CD image of my Acronis Boot Agent, so that I no longer need to boot from my CD ? Also, how do I setup my loot loader/boot manager with this option to boot from this special bootable partition ? Which tool would support this and how would I set this up ?
2) Also, does anyone know of a way to boot from an ISO image file stored on your hard drive ? Similar to question #1 above, except here I want my boot loader/boot manager/boot menu to give me the option to boot from an ISO image file stored on my hard drive. Again, is this possible ? Which tool would I need to use, and how would I achieve this ? Thanks for all your help !

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
Both grub4dos and syslinux allow to boot some .iso images. (but NOT "any" or "all" of them).  

Some Acronis products have been reported working with grub4dos mapping to (hd32), as an example "rescue CD" does:  
[http://www.boot-land...?...8774\&st=337](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8774&st=337 "External link")  
some don't or may not, first thing specify exactly the .iso you want/need to boot and then try searching the board, here is a similar thread with some links to check:  
[http://www.boot-land...showtopic=11167](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=11167 "External link")  

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  
Wonko

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> can you put a good tutorial in one place so we understand how it works? NO. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) You see, the problem is that to do so I should: * write a good tutorial * write the good tutorial for an app I don't use, I don't have, and probably will never need of which I know nothing ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png)
Sorry for not being up to your expectations ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif), but the only thing you will probably learn from a tutorial is "how to do it", by following my semi-random ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png) links it is more probable that you learn "how it works", instead. (if you survive the experience, of course ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)) Generally this kind of tutorials, just like batches, are made to "replicate" things, whilst articles, manuals and threads are made to exchange ideas and info and ultimately to "learn" things, in other words with tutorials you usually learn "what" to do as opposed to "why" and "how" you need to do it. If you want to \*learn\* "how it works" read the guide: [http://diddy.boot-la...os/Grub4dos.htm](http://diddy.boot-land.net/grub4dos/Grub4dos.htm "External link") and the stickies in the grub4dos Forum: [http://www.boot-land...hp?showforum=66](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showforum=66 "External link") then experiment (and possibly report your experience) ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko
